turtle_initialise.comments:
Initialise the library. Call turtle_finalise in order to unload the library. Optionally, an error handler might be provided.

Warnings

This function is not thread safe. Trying to re-initialise an already initialised library has unpredictable behaviour.

turtle_finalise.comments:
Unload the library. turtle_initialise must have been called first.

Warnings

This function is not thread safe. Trying to re-finalise an already finalised library has unpredictable behaviour.

turtle_strerror.comments: This function is analog to the C89 strerror function but specific to TURTLE return codes. It is thread safe.

turtle_strfunc.description: Return a string describing a TURTLE library function.
turtle_strfunc.comments: This function is meant for verbosing when handling errors. It is thread safe.

turtle_handler.comments: This function allows to set or alter the error handler. Only one error handler can be set at a time for all threads. It is not thread safe to modify it.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_projection_create.comments:
The currently supported projections are Lambert and UTM. The name, which encodes the projection parameters, must be as following:

* Lambert I

* Lambert II

* Lambert IIe    (for Lambert II extended)

* Lambert III

* Lambert IV

* Lambert 93     (conforming to RGF93)

* UTM {zone}{hemisphere}

* UTM {longitude}{hemisphere}

where {zone} is an integer in [1, 60] encoding the UTM world zone and hemisphere must be N for north or S for south, e.g. UTM 31N for the centre of France. Alternatively the central longitude of the UTM projection can be provided directly as an explicit floating number, e.g. UTM 3.0N for the UTM zone 31N as previously.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION    The name isn't valid.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR      The projection couldnt be allocated.

turtle_projection_destroy.comments:
Fully destroy a geographic projection previously allocated with turtle_projection_create. On return projection is set to NULL.

Warnings

This must not be called on a projection handle returned by a turtle_map. Instead one must call turtle_map_destroy to get rid of both the map and its projection.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_projection_configure.comments:
See turtle_projection_create for the supported projections and valid values for the name parameter.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION    The projection isn't supported.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_projection_info.comments:
This function fills in the provided name string with the projection details. The resulting name conforms to the inputs to turtle_projection_configure or turtle_projection_create, e.g. UTM 31N. See the later for a detailed description.

Warnings

This function allocates the name string. It is the user's responsability to free it when no more needed.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION    The projection isn't supported.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR      The name string couldn't be allocated.

turtle_projection_project.argline: const struct turtle_projection *projection, double latitude, double longitude, double *x, double *y

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_projection_project.description: Apply a geographic projection to geodetic coordinates.
turtle_projection_project.comments:
Apply the geographic projection to a set of geodetic coordinates. See turtle_projection_unproject for the reverse transform.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_ADDRESS       The projection is `NULL`.

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION    The projection isn't supported.

turtle_projection_unproject.argline: const struct turtle_projection *projection, double x, double y, double *latitude, double *longitude

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_projection_unproject.description: Unfold a geographic projection to recover the geodetic coordinates.
turtle_projection_unproject.comments:
Unfold a geographic projection to recover the initial geodetic coordinates. See turtle_projection_project for the direct transform.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_ADDRESS       The projection is `NULL`.

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION    The provided projection isn't supported.

args.name: projection
args.comment: The name of the projection or NULL.

args.name: box
args.comment: A bouding box for the map.

args.name: nx
args.comment: The number of nodes along the X-axis.

args.name: ny
args.comment: The number of nodes along the Y-axis.

args.name: bit_depth
args.comment: The number of bits for storing elevation values.

turtle_map_create.argline: const char *projection, const struct turtle_box *box, int nx, int ny, double zmin, double zmax, int bit_depth, struct turtle_map **map

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_map_create.comments:
Allocate memory for a new projection map and initialise it. Use turtle_map_destroy in order to recover the allocated memory. The map is initialised as flat with nx x ny static nodes of elevation zmin. The nodes are distributed over a regular grid defined by box. The elevation values are stored over bit_depth bits between zmin and zmax. If projection is not NULL the map is initialised with a geographic projection handle. See turtle_projection_create for a list of valid projections and their names.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION    An invalid projection was provided.

TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR      An input parameter is out of its validity range.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR      The map couldn't be allocated.

turtle_map_destroy.comments: Fully destroy a projection map and recover the memory previously allocated by turtle_projection_create. On return map is set to NULL.

args.name: path
args.comment: The path to the map file.

args.name: box
args.comment: A bouding box for the map or NULL.

turtle_map_load.argline: const char *path, const struct turtle_box *box, struct turtle_map **map

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_map_load.comments:
Load a projection map from a file. The file format is guessed from the filename's extension. Currently only a custom .png format is supported. A bouding box can be provided in order to load only a rectangular subset of the initial map. The bounding box coordinates must be specified in the initial map frame.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_EXTENSION    The file format is not supported.

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PATH         The file wasn't found.

TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR     The bouding box is invalid.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR     The map couldn't be allocated.

TURTLE_RETURN_XML_ERROR        The XML metadata are invalid (.png file).

args.name: path
args.comment: The path for the output file.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_map_dump.description: Dump a projection map to a file.
turtle_map_dump.comments:
Dump a projection map to a file. The file format is guessed from the output filename's extension. Currently only a custom .png format is supported.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_EXTENSION    The file format is not supported.

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT       The map cannot be dumped in the given format, e.g. 16 bit.

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PATH         The file couldn't be opened.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR     Some temporary memory couldn't be allocated.

turtle_map_fill.argline: struct turtle_map *map, int ix, int iy, double elevation

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_map_fill.description: Fill the elevation value of a map node.
turtle_map_fill.comments:
Fill the elevation value of the map node of coordinates (ix, iy). The elevation value must be in the range [zmin, zmax] of the map. Note that depending on the map's bit_depth the actual node elevation can differ from the input value by (zmax-zmin)/(2**(bit_depth)-1), e.g 1.5 cm for a 1 km altitude span and a 16 bit resolution.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR    Some input parameter isn't valid.

turtle_map_node.argline: struct turtle_map *map, int ix, int iy, double *x, double *y, double *elevation

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR if any input parameter isn't valid.

turtle_map_node.description: Get the properties of a map node.
turtle_map_node.comments: Get the properties of a map node, i.e. its geographic coordinates and elevation value.

turtle_map_elevation.argline: const struct turtle_map *map, double x, double y, double *elevation

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_map_elevation.description: Get the map elevation at a geographic coordinate.
turtle_map_elevation.comments:
Compute an estimate of the map elevation at the given geographic coordinates. The elevation is linearly interpolated using the 4 nodes that surround the given coordinate.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR    The coordinates are not valid.

return.comment: A handle to the map's projection or NULL if the map is NULL.

turtle_map_projection.description: Get a handle to the map's projection.
turtle_map_projection.comments: Note The provided projection handle allows to set and modify the map's projection, e.g. using turtle_projection_configure.

args.name: box
args.comment: The map bounding box in X-Y.

args.name: nx
args.comment: The number of nodes along the X-axis.

args.name: ny
args.comment: The number of nodes along the Y-axis.

args.name: bit_depth
args.comment: The number of bits for storing elevation values.

turtle_map_info.argline: const struct turtle_map *map, struct turtle_box *box, int *nx, int *ny, double *zmin, double *zmax, int *bit_depth
turtle_map_info.description: Get basic information on a projection map.
turtle_map_info.comments: Get some basic information on a projection map. Note that any output parameter can be set to NULL if the corresponding property is not needed.

args.name: path
args.comment: The path where elevation data are stored.

args.name: stack_size
args.comment: The number of elevation data tiles kept in memory.

args.name: lock
args.comment: A callback for locking critical sections, or NULL.

args.name: unlock
args.comment: A callback for unlocking critical sections, or NULL.

turtle_datum_create.argline: const char *path, int stack_size, turtle_datum_cb *lock, turtle_datum_cb *unlock, struct turtle_datum **datum

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_datum_create.comments:
Allocate memory for a new geodetic datum and initialise it. Use turtle_datum_destroy in order to recover any memory allocated subsequently. The datum is initialised with an empty stack. The name of the path folder encodes the data source as detailed below. It doesn't need to actually store elevation data, e.g. if only geographic transforms are needed.

Warnings

For multithreaded access to elevation data, using a turtle_client one must provide both a lock and unlock callback, e.g. based on sem_wait and sem_post. Otherwise they can be both set to NULL. Note that setting only one to not NULL raises a TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT error.

Supported sources

ASTGTM2    ASTER-GDEM2 data, e.g. from http://reverb.echo.nasa.gov/reverb.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_ADDRESS     The lock and unlock callbacks are inconsistent.

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT      The format of the elevation data is not supported.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR    The datum couldn't be allocated.

turtle_datum_destroy.comments:
Fully destroy a datum and all its allocated elevation data. On return datum is set to NULL.

Warnings

This method is not thread safe. All clients should have been destroyed or disabled first.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_datum_clear.comments:
Clear the stack from any elevation data not currently reserved by a turtle_client.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_LOCK_ERROR      The lock couldn't be acquired.

TURTLE_RETURN_UNLOCK_ERROR    The lock couldn't be released.

turtle_datum_elevation.argline: struct turtle_datum *datum, double latitude, double longitude, double *elevation

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_datum_elevation.comments:
Compute an estimate of the elevation at the given geodetic coordinates. The elevation is linearly interpolated using the 4 nodes that surround the given coordinate.

Warnings this function is not thread safe. A turtle_client must be used instead for concurrent accesses to the datum elevation data.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PATH    The required elevation data are not in the datum's path.

turtle_datum_ecef.argline: struct turtle_datum *datum, double latitude, double longitude, double elevation, double [3] ecef

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_datum_ecef.description: Transform geodetic coordinates to cartesian ECEF ones.
turtle_datum_ecef.comments:
Transform geodetic coordinates to Cartesian ones in the Earth-Centered, Earth-Fixed (ECEF) frame.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT   The data source is not supported.

turtle_datum_geodetic.argline: struct turtle_datum *datum, double [3] ecef, double *latitude, double *longitude, double *elevation

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_datum_geodetic.description: Transform cartesian ECEF coordinates to geodetic ones.
turtle_datum_geodetic.comments:
Transform Cartesian coordinates in the Earth-Centered, Earth-Fixed (ECEF) frame to geodetic ones. B. R. Bowring's (1985) algorithm's is used with a single iteration.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT   The data source is not supported.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_client_create.description: Create a new client for a geodetic datum.
turtle_client_create.comments:
Allocate memory for a new client for a thread safe access to the elevation data of a geodetic datum. The client is initialised as iddle. Whenever a new elevation value is requested it will book the needed data to its master turtle_datum and release any left over ones. Use turtle_client_clearin order to force the release of any reserved data or turtle_client_destroy in order to fully recover the client's memory.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_ADDRESS     The datum is not valid, e.g. has no lock.

TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR    The client couldn't be allocated.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_client_destroy.description: Create a new client for a geodetic datum.
turtle_client_destroy.comments:
Attempts to destroy a datum client. Any reserved elevation data are first freed. On a successfull return client is set to NULL.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_LOCK_ERROR      The lock couldn't be acquired.

TURTLE_RETURN_UNLOCK_ERROR    The lock couldn't be released.

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_client_clear.comments:
Notify the master datum that any previously reserved elevation data is no more needed.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_LOCK_ERROR      The lock couldn't be acquired.

TURTLE_RETURN_UNLOCK_ERROR    The lock couldn't be released.

turtle_client_elevation.argline: struct turtle_client *client, double latitude, double longitude, double *elevation

return.comment: On success TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS is returned otherwise an error code is returned as detailed below.

turtle_client_elevation.description: Thread safe access to the elevation data of a geodetic datum.
turtle_client_elevation.comments:
Compute an estimate of the elevation at the given geodetic coordinates. The elevation is linearly interpolated using the 4 nodes that surround the given coordinate.

Error codes

TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PATH        The required elevation data are not in the datum's path.

TURTLE_RETURN_LOCK_ERROR      The lock couldn't be acquired.

TURTLE_RETURN_UNLOCK_ERROR    The lock couldn't be released.

turtle_caller_t.comments: This is a generic function pointer used to identify the library functions, e.g. for error handling.

args.name: caller
args.comment: The caller function where the error occured.

turtle_handler_cb.comments:
The user might provide its own error handler. It will be called at the return of any TURTLE library function providing an error code.

Warnings

This callback must be thread safe if a turtle_client is used.

return.comment: 0 on success, any other value otherwise.

turtle_datum_cb.description: Callback for locking or unlocking critical sections.
turtle_datum_cb.comments:
For multhithreaded applications with a turtle_datum and turtle_clients the user must supply a lock and unlock callback providing exclusive access to critical sections, e.g. using a semaphore.

Warnings

The callback must return 0 if the (un)lock was successfull.

types.block:
double x0
double y0
double half_x
double half_y

types.description: Handle to a datum client for multithreaded access to elevation data.
Handle for a geodetic datum for worldwide elevation data.
Handle for a projection map of the elevation.

types.block:
TURTLE_RETURN_SUCCESS
TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_ADDRESS
TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_EXTENSION
TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT
TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PATH
TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_PROJECTION
TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_XML
TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR
TURTLE_RETURN_LIBRARY_ERROR
TURTLE_RETURN_LOCK_ERROR
TURTLE_RETURN_MEMORY_ERROR
TURTLE_RETURN_UNLOCK_ERROR
N_TURTLE_RETURNS

fields.name: TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_ADDRESS
fields.comments: A wrong pointer address was provided, e.g. NULL.

fields.name: TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_EXTENSION
fields.comments: A provided file extension is not supported or recognised.

fields.name: TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_FORMAT
fields.comments: A provided file or string has a wrong format.

fields.name: TURTLE_RETURN_BAD_XML
fields.comments: A provided XML section was not understood.

fields.name: TURTLE_RETURN_DOMAIN_ERROR
fields.comments: Some input parameters are out of their validity range.

fields.name: TURTLE_RETURN_LIBRARY_ERROR
fields.comments: An TURTLE low level library error occured.

fields.name: N_TURTLE_RETURNS
fields.comments: The number of TURTLE error codes.
